newsitem.title: UK: INSIGHT-IPE Brent to move up but resistance strong.
newsitem.headline: INSIGHT-IPE Brent to move up but resistance strong.

text.p: NEARBY MONTH CLOSE * SUPPORT * RESIST * RSI-14 * MA-10 * MA-20
* The market closed above the 40-day moving average at $18.74 on Tuesday and will look for initial support here and then at $18.50.
* Momentum indicators continue to point the market higher though there is some strong resistance to break down before $19, which marks a 50 percent Fibonacci retracement, can be achieved.
The uptrend for IPE Brent crude looks set to continue though its pace may be slowed for a while with bearish chart formations on gas oil possibly flagging the end of its recent surge, analysts said.
Darren Gurner, analyst at Sucden, said, "In the short term supports for Brent look good and in the longer term I think we will see $19."

He said the market closed above the 40-day moving average at $18.74 on Tuesday and would look for initial support here and then at $18.50. But he said momentum indicators continued to point the market higher though there was some strong resistance to break down before $19, which marks a 50 percent Fibonacci retracement, would be hit.
"If it gets through $19 the market could be on the road to recovery, $19.50 is psychological but after this there is very little resistance to $20," Gurner said.
Al Graham at Elliott Wave International, Gainesville, Florida warned of a "massive wall of resistance" that is thought to reside between $19.02 and $19.37 and he took a bearish longer-term view.
"Dropping under $18.45 makes the case that projected weakness is underway, while breaking $18.67 support is a solid indication that the weakness is likely to progress," Graham said.
However, an expanding triangle formation on the August chart flags continuation of the current trend, but analysts are still looking for confirmation that the market can sustain recent gains.
"There may initially be some correction on crude if gas oil turns tail and head lower, but good supports are now in place at the mid to lower $18 level," one analyst said.
Analysts said the market remains bullish for the short term but needs to keep its upside momentum rolling forward in order to avoid triggering a sharp sell-off if confidence runs out.

Gas oil continued to strengthen on Tuesday after breaking down resistance at $167.25 the top of a gap down earlier in the month to close at $167.75. The next target could be the $179.50 high from mid-May, but analysts said the narrow trading ranges over the last few days may mean the market is running out of steam to the upside.
Using Japanese candlestick charting techniques a "hanging man" pattern, where the bulk of trade was toward the top of the daily range, at this point could be signalling the end of the recent rally.
Graham said, "Expect prices to fall under 158 from little, if any, above $171.50-$172 and probably starting within a day or so."
August Brent on SIMEX was trading around $18.65 per barrel, after London settled 29 cents higher at $18.80.
On ACCESS NYMEX crude valued around $20.02, down 10 cents from the New York close where the contract gained 32 cents to settle at $20.12 a barrel.
--Colin Wooster, London Newsroom, +44 171 542 7456
